questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: de-Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves tendon sheath of which two muscles? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic. The examiner places patient’s thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction. In positive test this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the opposite thumb is relatively painless.

 

 

Finkelstein’s test – de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

 

  • Differential diagnosis: 
    • Scaphoid non-union
    • Arthritis at the base of thumb
    • Intersection syndrome
       
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

choices.text: Thayer Martin agar
Wilson Blair agar

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. The best culture media for the following organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thayer Martin agar

 

The patient’s symptoms of urethral discharge, dysuria, and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse suggest an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a fastidious bacterium requiring enriched media for growth. Thayer Martin agar is a selective medium specifically designed to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It contains nutrients that support the growth of Neisseria species and antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to inhibit the growth of contaminating organisms, making it the best medium for culturing this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood agar: Although blood agar is a general-purpose nutrient medium that can support the growth of a wide range of bacteria, it is not selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and does not contain the necessary inhibitors to prevent the growth of other organisms.

 

Option B. MacConkey agar: This agar is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria and is typically used for isolating lactose-fermenting bacteria like Escherichia coli. It is not suitable for the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which does not thrive on this medium.

 

Option D. Wilson Blair agar: This medium is used for isolating Salmonella typhi and is not relevant to Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as it does not provide the specific growth conditions required for this organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thayer Martin agar is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a bacterium associated with sexually transmitted infections presenting as urethral discharge and dysuria.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain. His amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enzymatic fat necrosis

 

The patient, a chronic alcoholic, presents with abdominal pain and elevated levels of amylase and lipase, which are indicative of pancreatitis. In cases of both acute and chronic pancreatitis, the typical pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis. This occurs when pancreatic enzymes, particularly lipase, escape into the surrounding tissues, leading to fat digestion and necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically associated with ischemic injury, such as myocardial infarction, and is characterized by the preservation of cellular outlines.

 

Option C. Caseous necrosis: This type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculosis infections and some fungal infections. It presents with a cheese-like appearance and is not associated with pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis:  This type of necrosis is usually seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels, such as in vasculitis or severe hypertension, where immune complexes and fibrin are deposited in vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pancreatitis, especially in chronic alcoholics, the characteristic pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis, resulting from the action of pancreatic enzymes on the surrounding fatty tissues.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the Flexor Carpi Radialis.
  • The flexor carpi radialis muscle is a long, superficial muscle of the forearm that belongs to the anterior muscle group and lies in the first layer.
  • It is a relatively thin muscle located on the anterior part of the forearm.
  • It arises in the humerus epicondyle, close to the wrist area.
  • It is a superficial muscle that becomes very visible as the wrist comes into flexion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris: The flexor carpi ulnaris can be palpated by locating the bony landmarks associated to the muscle including the medial epicondyle, the olecranon process and the pisiform bone. After identifying the bony landmarks, the person is asked to perform ulnar deviation and wrist flexion simultaneously, which will help locate the FCU muscle.

 

 

Option. C. Palmaris Longus: The Palmaris longus (PL) muscle is a long, slender muscle which is usually present in the superficial volar compartment of the forearm, interposed between the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and the Flexor Carpi Radialis muscles. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

 

Option. D. Extensor Carpi Radialis: Extensor carpi radialis is a muscle that can be found in the posterior compartment of the forearm. It is partly overlapped by brachioradialis and these muscles often blend together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The marked muscle tendon in the image is of the flexor carpi radialis muscle.

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

 

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

 

Mutations:

 

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

 

Treatment:

 

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B:  Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism

 

Option C: TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth

 

Option D:  Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • The images show the cervical vertebrae where, at the lower cervical spine (C4-C7), there is an anterior slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. 
  • In the left image, C5 appears to be shifted anteriorly relative to C6. 
  • This slippage is referred to as spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis involves forward displacement of one vertebra over another.
  • Pathology:
    • The pars interarticularis is disrupted on both sides (spondylolysis), separating the posterior neural arch from vertebral body; gap is later filled by fibrous tissue.
    • The vertebral body undergoes anterior dislocation under stress.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Lateral view: Forward shift of the upper part of spinal column on the stable vertebra below; elongation of the arch or defective facets may be seen.
    • Oblique views are needed to clearly demonstrate fracture of pars interarticularis (Beheaded Scottie dog sign)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a systemic condition characterized by reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), and codfish appearance. It typically appears as generalized radiolucency (bones look "thinner" or "washed out") and potentially vertebral compression fractures. 

 

 

Option C. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect or fracture at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. It is difficult to definitively diagnose spondylolysis on a plain lateral cervical X-ray without oblique views or a CT.  

 

 

Option D. Discitis. This is an or infection of the intervertebral disc and adjacent vertebral bodies. Radiographically, it would typically show disc space narrowing. This is not the primary finding observed in these images. Discitis is a serious but uncommon infection or inflammation of the intervertebral disc space. Radiographic findings include the narrowing of disc space, irregular endplates, and sometimes erosions or sclerosis of the vertebral bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the given question shows spondylolisthesis of C6 vertebra over C7 vertebra.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

It is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to gradually deteriorate, eventually leading to thyroid failure. It is most common in women between the ages of 45 and 65. The presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase causes it.

 

There is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with an intact capsule morphologically. It is clearly separated from the surrounding structures.

 

There are two types of Hashimoto's thyroiditis: the classic form, which is more common, and the fibrosing variant, which occurs in only 10% of cases.

 

The classic form is distinguished by diffuse, symmetric, firm, and rubbery thyroid enlargement. The fibrosing variant has a firm, enlarged thyroid with surrounding tissue compression.

 

Histologically:

 

  1. Classic form has intense lymphocytic infiltration, atrophied thyroid follicles, and follicular epithelial cells that have degenerated into Hurthle cells (also called Askanazy cells, or oxyphil cells, or oncocytes).
  2. The fibrosing variant of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by significant fibrous replacement of thyroid parenchyma and a less prominent lymphoid infiltrate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graves' disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, presence of anti-TSH receptor antibodies, and typically does not present with Hurthle cells.

 

  • Clinical features include exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and a diffusely enlarged hypervascular thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma: A type of thyroid cancer that presents with different histological features, such as follicular cell proliferation and capsular or vascular invasion, but not typically Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with amyloid deposits and elevated calcitonin levels.

 

  • Histologically different from Hashimoto's thyroiditis and does not feature Hurthle cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. One of the well-known side effects of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which can lead to color vision defects, particularly with the perception of red and green. Patients on ethambutol are usually monitored for visual acuity and color vision changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is used to treat various bacterial infections, including tuberculosis (TB). While it has a range of side effects, red color vision defects or optic neuropathy are not typically associated with rifampicin. It is more commonly known to cause orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. INH (Isoniazid): INH, or isoniazid, is another first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects can include peripheral neuropathy, which is why it is often given with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to mitigate this risk. However, INH is not commonly associated with red color vision defects or optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an anti-TB drug, can cause optic neuropathy and red color vision defects, necessitating regular eye exams for patients on this medication.

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere
Inferior frontal gyrus of the right hemisphere
Superior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere
Superior temporal gyrus of the right hemisphere

questions.text: A right-handed individual exhibits non-fluent aphasia with intact comprehension. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has non-fluent aphasia with intact comprehension, which is characteristic of Broca's aphasia. Broca's aphasia results from damage to the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) in the dominant hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals. This area is supplied by the superior division of the middle cerebral artery. In Broca's aphasia, speech production is impaired (non-fluent) while comprehension remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior frontal gyrus of the right hemisphere: In right-handed individuals, language functions are usually lateralized to the left hemisphere. The right inferior frontal gyrus is not primarily responsible for language production, so damage here would not typically cause non-fluent aphasia.

 

Option C. Superior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere: Damage to this area (Wernicke's area) causes a different type of aphasia characterized by fluent speech with poor comprehension (Wernicke's aphasia), which is the opposite of what the patient exhibits.

 

Option D. Superior temporal gyrus of the right hemisphere: Similar to option B, the right hemisphere in right-handed individuals is not dominant for language functions. Damage to this area would not typically cause aphasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Non-fluent aphasia with preserved comprehension (Broca's aphasia) results from damage to the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) in the dominant hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals.

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Purkinje cells are specialized neurons located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Golgi cells: These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

 

Option D. Granule cells:

 

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have a large, flask-shaped soma from which extend many branching dendrites. The dendritic tree is oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the cerebellum, extending into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass into the white matter and are the only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex to synapse with cells in the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor X inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that functions as a direct Factor Xa inhibitor. Factor Xa plays a crucial role in the coagulation cascade, leading to the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, which subsequently forms fibrin clots. By inhibiting Factor Xa, Rivaroxaban effectively prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation, providing anticoagulant effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct Thrombin inhibitor: Drugs that act as direct thrombin inhibitors include Dabigatran, Argatroban, Bivalirudin, and Lepirudin. These drugs directly inhibit thrombin, preventing the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option C. Increased ATIII activity: This mechanism is associated with heparins and heparinoids. These drugs enhance the activity of antithrombin III (ATIII), which inactivates thrombin and other proteases involved in blood clotting.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibition: Warfarin and other coumarin derivatives inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. This reduces the body's ability to form clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct Factor Xa inhibitor, which prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Arrange in order the disaster management cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impact → response → rehabilitation → mitigation

 

Explanation:

 

The correct chronological order of the disaster management cycle is as follows:

 

5 stages -

 

  1. Impact: This is the initial stage when a disaster strikes an area, such as an earthquake, flood, or tsunami.
  2. Response: In this stage, search and rescue operations, first aid, and medical relief efforts are launched.
  3. Rehabilitation: This stage focuses on addressing water, sanitation, food supply, vector control, and other essential services.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts are made to prevent hazards or risks from turning into disasters, minimizing potential damage.
  5. Preparedness: This stage involves planning and preparation for an anticipated disaster, such as a tsunami or earthquake season.

 

The answer to this is choice A, which correctly arranges the stages as impact, response, rehabilitation, and mitigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of the disaster management cycle is impact, response, rehabilitation, mitigation, and preparedness, representing the chronological sequence of actions taken during and after a disaster.

choices.text: In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

questions.text: How does the murmur of severe aortic regurgitation differ from that of mild aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

 

Explanation:

 

In severe aortic regurgitation, the diastolic pressure half-time is significantly shorter (<200 ms) compared to mild AR (>500 ms). This occurs because as AR severity increases, the pressure between the aorta and left ventricle equalizes more rapidly during diastole, resulting in a shorter murmur duration. The characteristic murmur is high-pitched, diastolic, and decrescendo in nature, best heard at Erb's area with the patient leaning forward, but in severe AR it terminates earlier in diastole due to this rapid pressure equalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch - Incorrect because the murmur of AR is characteristically high-pitched regardless of severity, heard best with the diaphragm of the stethoscope.

 

Option B. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type - Incorrect because AR murmurs are typically decrescendo in configuration, beginning loudly and diminishing in intensity as diastole progresses, reflecting the decreasing pressure gradient.

 

Option C. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity - Incorrect because severe AR is typically associated with a louder murmur due to greater regurgitant flow, not softer intensity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The duration of an aortic regurgitation murmur is inversely related to its severity - severe AR produces a shorter diastolic murmur due to more rapid pressure equalization between the aorta and left ventricle, as evidenced by a shorter pressure half-time (<200 ms in severe AR versus >500 ms in mild AR)

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening of immigrants to a country

 

Prospective screening is conducted primarily for the benefit of the community or the public health system, rather than for the direct benefit of the individual being screened. It aims to control the spread of diseases and protect public health by identifying potential carriers of infectious diseases or individuals with certain health conditions that may pose a risk to others.

 

Screening of immigrants to a country: This is a classic example of prospective screening. It is done to detect infectious diseases or other health conditions in immigrants to prevent the spread of disease and protect the health of the population in the host country. This screening is often mandated by public health authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient:  This is an example of prescriptive screening, as it is conducted for the individual's benefit to detect cervical cancer early.

 

Option B. Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism:  This is also an example of prescriptive screening aimed at early detection and management of hypothyroidism in newborns.

 

Option D. Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man:  This is another example of prescriptive screening, used to detect diabetes in the individual.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which bones are cut during external DCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary, lacrimal

 

In external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR),  the maxillary bone is involved because it forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and part of the orbit. The lacrimal bone is also involved because it contains the lacrimal sac fossa. The surgery involves creating a direct opening between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing part of the lacrimal bone and the adjacent part of the maxillary bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoid, Sphenoid: The ethmoid and sphenoid bones are part of the skull's cranial base and are not typically involved in an external DCR. The ethmoid bone does contribute to the medial wall of the orbit and contains the ethmoid air cells, while the sphenoid bone is part of the skull base and contains the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option B. Ethmoid, Lacrimal: The lacrimal bone is a small bone forming part of the eye socket, and it is indeed involved in DCR as it forms part of the lateral nasal wall and houses part of the nasolacrimal duct. The ethmoid bone, as mentioned, is part of the medial orbital wall but is not typically cut during an external DCR procedure.

 

Option D. Nasal, Lacrimal: The nasal bone forms the bridge of the nose and is not typically modified during an external DCR. The lacrimal bone is involved in the procedure as mentioned, but the nasal bones are not cut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the maxillary and lacrimal bones are cut to establish a new tear drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic changes is most commonly associated with hyperemesis gravidarum? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperthyroidism

 

Hyperthyroidism is the metabolic change most commonly associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. This connection exists because of the similarity in structure between hCG and TSH. During pregnancy, especially in the first trimester when hyperemesis occurs, hCG has intrinsic thyrotropic activity that can lead to a state of physiological hyperthyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernatremia is not typically associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. In fact, with severe vomiting, patients are more likely to develop hyponatremia due to fluid losses and potential water retention from ADH release.

 

Option C. Hyperchloremia is not a characteristic metabolic change in hyperemesis gravidarum. Electrolyte disturbances are common, but typically manifest as hypochloremia due to loss of chloride in vomitus.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia is not associated with hyperemesis gravidarum. Severe vomiting more commonly leads to hypokalemia due to potassium loss in vomitus and secondary aldosteronism from volume depletion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hyperemesis gravidarum is associated with hyperthyroidism due to the thyrotropic activity of elevated hCG levels, which can mimic TSH action on thyroid receptors.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and right index finger pain. Biochemical analysis showed raised indirect bilirubin. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sickle cell anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The combination of symptoms, including fatigue, lethargy, pallor (suggesting anemia), right index finger pain, and elevated indirect bilirubin levels (indicating jaundice), strongly points toward sickle cell anemia as the underlying diagnosis.

Sickle cell anemia is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the production of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells, which can lead to vaso-occlusive crises and ischemic damage.

 

The presence of right index finger pain is a crucial clue, as it may be a manifestation of dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome, which is commonly seen in sickle cell anemia patients. This condition arises due to the involvement of small blood vessels in the hands and feet, leading to inflammation and severe pain.

 

Additionally, the hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) associated with sickle cell anemia results in anemia and elevated indirect bilirubin levels, causing jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: While thalassemia is also a type of hemolytic anemia, it does not typically present with the characteristic hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis seen in sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells by the body's own immune system. It does not typically cause the specific symptom of index finger pain.

 

Option D. PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria): PNH is a rare acquired disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with the combination of symptoms seen in this case, particularly the right index finger pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, jaundice, and specific finger pain (dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome), sickle cell anemia should be strongly considered as the underlying diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is the most resistant to antiseptics? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Prions

 

Explanation:

 

Prions are the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfectants. Prions require specific and extreme sterilization methods compared to other microorganisms. The recommended methods for prion sterilization are particularly aggressive: autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours, treatment with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour, or using 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spores - While bacterial spores are highly resistant to many antiseptics, they are less resistant than prions. Spores can be killed by proper autoclaving (121°C for 15 minutes) or using strong disinfectants like glutaraldehyde (2% for 10-14 hours).

 

Option C. Cysts - Cysts of protozoa are moderately resistant to antiseptics but less resistant than both spores and prions. They don't require the extreme conditions needed for prion inactivation.

 

Option D. Fungi - Fungi are generally susceptible to intermediate-level disinfectants. Intermediate-level disinfectants including alcohols, phenolics, and halogens are effective against fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions require the most extreme sterilization conditions of all infectious agents, including extended high-temperature autoclaving (134°C for 1-1.5 hours) or strong chemical treatment (1N NaOH or concentrated hypochlorite), making them the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfection methods.

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

 

Explanation

 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):

 

MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:

 

  1. Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  2. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  3. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  4. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.

 

Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:

 

  • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.

 

Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.

 

Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
